, Piracicaba is regarded as one of the most pleasant medium-sized cities in the state. Attractions of the city include a charming riverside area, historical heritage, Tyrolese villages and the beautiful campus of the agriculture school of University of São Paulo.
is undoubtedly the largest city and economic powerhouse of the
, but hardly any city of the region beats Piracicaba in terms of cultural vibrancy. The city has several cultural centers, annual traditions from both
and immigrant origins, and is the birthplace of the

.

Founded in 1776 at the shores of the Piracicaba river, the so-called

grew with sugarcane production, unlike most of the São Paulo state which grew with coffee farming. Thanks to city council member Prudente de Moraes, who would later become the first civil president of Brazil, in 1881 Vila Nova da Constituição changed its name to
. Sugarcane remains very important to the city's economy, as Piracicaba is a major producer of ethanol.

value: content=The pedestrianized street in the front of the Piracicaba river, containing old, colorful fisherman houses, is not only a place with excellent bars and restaurants, but also where the city was first settled.
content=This 19th-century house is used as tourist information center, and hosts some cultural expositions. Not open on Monday.
content=A small segmented waterfall in the Piracicaba River.
content=Park by the Piracicaba river, that provides some nice views of the segmented waterfall, the Rua do Porto, and the city center.
content=With an area of 85 thousand square meters, the "Barão de Rezende" sugar mill, constructed in a 1881, is a valuable historical heritage. It hosts several cultural events.
content=Built in 1887, the old water catchment station is now an educational museum and offers some nice views of the Piracicaba river.
content=Rammed-earth house constructed between the 18th and 19th centuries, used to host small expositions.
directions=North of Parque Mirante, on the SP-127 bridge
content=Tourist elevator on the bridge above the Piracicaba waterfall.  Good view of downtown and river.
content=Former school founded in 1881 by an American missionary, nowadays a cultural center.

content=Museum dedicated to the history of Piracicaba and Brazil's first civil president, Prudente de Moraes, who lived in the same construction during the XIX century. Built in an eclectic style, it is a national heritage site.
address=R. Dom Pedro x R. Gov. Pedro de Toledo

content=The Methodist church in Piracicaba started with American missionaries, the same ones who founded the Colégio Piracicabano and the Universidade Metodista de Piracicaba (UNIMEP). The current construction is from 1922.
content=The contemporary-style building hosts temporary art expositions.
name=Igreja Nossa Senhora da Boa Morte
content=The church and the annex school (former

) were founded in 1893 by Salesian nuns, intended to compete with the Methodist Colégico Piracicabano. Colégio Assunção (nowadays Colégio Dom Bosco Assunção) used to be a girls-only school, where women of some of the wealthiest families in the region have studied.
content=Historical public school, founded in 1897. Its charming facade illustrates the high quality of Brazilian public schools at the end of the XIX century.
address=R. Treze de Maio x R. do Rosário - Centro
content=Another fancy-looking public school, founded in 1900.
alt=Igreja Sagrado Coração de Jesus de Piracicaba
address=Rua São Francisco de Assis, 640 - Centro
content=Church founded in 1897 by Capuchin friars from
, also to contain the expansion of the Methodist church in the city.
address=Av. Dr. Paulo de Moraes, 1540 - Paulista
content=Piracicaba's train station, inaugurated in 1922 and deactivated in 1970. Now it hosts a cultural center.
content=Piracicaba's central square, where the city's cathedral, built in 1959 in Romantic style, is located. Hosts a handcrafts fair in the first week of each month.
address=Rua Governador Pedro de Toledo, between R. Dom Pedro I and R. Dom Pedro II
content=Market with individual stalls: fruit/veg, meat, pastaleria.
alt=Escola Superior de Agricultura Luiz de Queiroz

content=The University of São Paulo's agriculture school, founded in 1901, is also one of the Piracicaba's main postcards. Its attractions are its beautiful, early 20th century buildings and surrounding green areas.
content=This impressive construction, from 1917, hosts a public school founded by the Italian educator Sud Mennuci. It was used in the past for preparing teachers, hence the sign "Escola Normal".
content=The "other" Dom Bosco Catholic school, located in a beautiful eclectic structure, inaugurated in 1950.
address=Rua Bom Jesus x Rua Morais Barros - Cidade Alta
content=Beautiful Catholic church decorated with angels and a Christ the Redeemer statue.

content=A historical neighborhood built around the "Monte Alegre" sugarcane mill, founded in 1824 and deactivated in 1980. Along with the mill, it also contains a church, constructed in 1936, and several worker houses previously inhabited by Italian immigrants. Many constructions are in poor state, although a revitalization process has been started recently.
directions=About 8 km from the center of Piracicaba
content=Santa Olímpia is a rural Tyrolese neighborhood that maintains strong traditions. It is best visited during a cultural event such as the Festival da Polenta.
content=15-minute boat rides along the Piracicaba river, departing at Rua do Porto. Day trips to other municipalities (like
content=Handcrafts fair that typically happens in Rua do Porto during saturdays and sundays. Check the website for exact dates.
content=Handcrafts fair that happens in the city center, starting in the first tuesday of each month and ending on saturdays. Check the website for exact dates.
Rua do Porto, next to the Piracicaba river, is one of the city's main gastronomic centers.

Piracicaba's most famous local dish is the
("fish in the drum"), served on Rua do Porto. Piracicaba is also famous for its

, a dessert made of mashed corn, milk (or coconut milk), sugar, cinnamon, butter and fennel, produced in the rural neighborhood of Tanquinho. The restaurants of the Santa Olímpia neighborhood also offer dishes of Tyrolese origin, like polenta with chicken, canederli and polenta
